reviews.review: Better than Half-Life. More enemies, more weapons, and more NPCs to help you.
With no cut scenes, this game tells a far more engaging story than a game with one.
You play Half-Life in the perspective of a HECU Soldier named adrian shephard.

A great lenghty expansion to the original Half-Life, in some ways I think I even liked it more. Some key moments from the base story are mirrored, as you now play at the opposite side as a marine. New gameplay elements, weapons, enemies (including epic bossfights), highly recommended!

Half-Life: Opposing Force is a spin-off of the original Half-Life that takes place during the original game's storyline and it was made by Gearbox Software (not Valve) in 1999. You play as Adrian Shepard, one of the militaries that you fight during the original Half-Life.

I'm not going to write a full review, but I'll say that I've found the title to be entertaining. It also adds some details to the plot of the first game, which will help the player to understand it better. 
New weapons are introduced, which help to refresh the experience a bit.

I'd recommend it to every player who wants to know a bit more of the storyline of the original game, and want to know what happens to Black Mesa after Gordon's Story, and I'd give the title a 8/10.

Half-Life: Opposing Force.
I wish I could even play it because it's apparently one of the best expansions out there, but I can't for 2 reasons.

1. I apparently can't turn one way or the other without the screen locking me back to where I was looking before. The screen jitters around whenever I try to force it to turn and my mouse works perfectly fine, so it's something with the game itself.

2. In my attempt to fix this issue, I accidentally turned up the resolution and widescreen settings and now I can't even play the game because the screen and the pause menu are super zoomed in and I can't even access the VIDEO section of the options menu to return it to normal.

uninstalling then reinstalling didn't fix the second issue, which means I can't even see if it fixed the first issue.

Overall, I imagine it's great. It's just too bad I can't play it now because of a glitch in the system and poor resolution settings that I can't fix.

I'm probably just gonna hunt down the OG version of this game if I can. If you have any of these issues, I'd recommend you do the same.

good game

This game is very good, but it has a lot of flaws, and it isn't better than Half-Life for me like most people say. My biggest problem with the game is that it rips off a lot of things from the first Half-Life and reskin them. Another problem is that if Half-Life had an inconsistent difficulty, this one has a consistent one: difficult all the way through. Of course you're supposed to play it after Half-Life, but this is an extra, it should be just some nice extra content. Idk, just some personal problems with the game.
Overall: 8.5/10

This first expansion of Classic Half-Life, like Blue Shift, I had never played back in the day, but have just played through both recently. (can't really review this without making comparisons between the two)  While Blue Shift has good quality level design, polished and is a smooth playthrough (GearBox seemed to take a different approach after a couple years of looking at Opposing Force) however no new content outside of the levels themselves. OF is just the opposite, unbalanced, awkward, simply feels like a bunch of incomplete efforts all thrown together (hey it's content).  However OF introduces new weapons, enemies, squadmates, the infamous Black Ops, and a couple facepalm bosses. The main issue is all this new content is where the flaws with this game shine through.  

The weapons are terribly unbalanced, and there are simply too many of them.  The shotgun is massively underpowered, takes 3-4 point blank double blasts to take down anything, pretty much the entire clip defeating the whole purpose of ever choosing a shotgun for close quarter combat.  The standard machine gun is the same problem, gotta empty the whole clip to even get a kill.  Whereas the  the laser pointer pistol takes about 2 shots to kill most enemies, near the power of the sniper rifle.  Aside from the laser pistol and sniper rifle, both of which you rarely have ammo for, the Heavy Machine Gun is the only effective, non-explosive weapon in your arsenal.  The Electrical charge alien gun doesn't do enough damage, just another weapon to clutter up the selection.  The version of the BFG has a unique alternate fire with dimensional side effects, though it doesn't really prove helpful, it is quite intriguing.  The Alien Grenade launcher is decent, but still seems to not do as much damage as it should, much like the rocket launcher.  still gotta throw 4+ into the big aliens that you gotta fight over and over in the sewer level near the end.  You can break crates and come across a trove of ammo and you'll know it is only going to get you through a few enemies.  Just feels like you gotta sit there forever either exploiting the flaws of the AI and burning through clip after clip just to kill anything.  You are better off just running past most enemies as it isn't worth the time/health/effort to sit there emptying clip after clip when you can just run and jump, essentially speed run approach to get through areas.  Black Ops can be dealt with in either of these ways as well, although it is often best to hide somewhere while they keep throwing grenades around and eventually blow themselves up.  And of course the squadron AI is atrocious, luckily there is only one sequence where you have to keep one of them alive.

OF should take most about 6 hours to beat on hard mode first try, although gotta consider there will be a lot of autosave reloading until you get a hang of how combat has to be dealt with (those Black Ops hehe, probably the best part of OF). Whereas BS is very short, easily completed on Hard Mode first try in less than 3 hours, forgettable ending, no new enemies or weapons.  OF does bring some new content to the table, although not delivered very well. Honestly I may play through OF again to see if I get a different impression but BS is just a much better quality experience.  I love difficult games (classic ones for sure), which is the main issue with BS, it is not.  While striving to do something new, OF is unbalanced and awkward, left to either run by enemies/exploit bad AI or tediously battle through with the tiny bits of ammo on the extremely inconsistently balanced weapons.  What Blue Shift lacks, OF's attempts to cover that feels like a constant fumble.  Whereas Blue Shift didn't introduce anything new and was very short, it plays much better than OF.  But as I wrote a review for BS before this one I realized that for me BS overall is just going to be forgettable in comparison to the aspirational but massively flawed OF.

Let's start with what this game is not. Half-Life: Opposing Force is not a full sequel to Half-Life. It is not a major paradigm shift in gaming. It is not perfect.

However, OF is one thing. It is an incredibly solid expansion to Half-Life that is 100% worth playing if you enjoyed the original game. This game goes out of its way to add new mechanics, enemies, and environments that make the already-stellar narrative at Black Mesa feel even more fleshed out. While this game stumbles in a few places, it's an easy recommendation for anyone who loved the original game.

Must have if you've played and liked Half Life.
I loved Blue Shift, Opposing Force is even better.

Half-Life: Opposing Force has you playing as Corporal Adrian Shephard who's one of the US Marines assaulting the Black Mesa Research Facility after the Resonance Cascade that caused the portal to be opened to the aliens dimension. It shows what happened to the research facility after Gordan Freeman's story was over.

This is a wonderful expansion! Half-Life: Opposing Force is even better than the main Half-Life game IMO. Thanks to multiple changes to the gameplay that amount to quality of life improvements. One example is in Half-Life there are some areas that are really dark so the game gives you a flashlight. But the light from the flashlight is just a tiny decal that only lights up a small area making it hard to use effectively. In Opposing Force you have night vision goggles which pretty much fixes that problem. Another stand out example is in the main Half-Life game most of the enemies have projectile weapons that are impossible to doge. In Opposing Force there's new enemies and you can actually doge their projectiles. Turning strafing into a viable tactic most of the time.

Blue Shift felt like the devs just took some assets from the main game and used those to make an expansion without adding any thing new. The tutorial for Blue Shift is basically a recycled version of the tutorial from the main game. But the tutorial in Opposing Force is totally unique with a whole new level where you start out in a marian boot camp. In Blue Shift you got some of the same weapons that Gordan Freeman used in the main game, but nothing new. In Opposing Force there are multiple new guns added to the game and they're actually pretty good. There's a squad system where you can get the other solders to help you fight your way through the facility. Some of the solders will be a special class such as a welder with a blow torch that can cut down some doors to get to optional areas with supplies. As well as a medic that can heal you. In the main game you could get some people to help you fight but you could only have one escort at a time. In Opposing Force you can have three or fore guys with you at once, although the path finding is still awful. There's also this alien grappling hook thing that you can use to grapple on to certain points and most of the trickier platforming sections are centered around using it. I still don't like the platforming but using the grappling hook to get around is still better then the tedious platforming puzzles from Blue Shift.

If I ever replay Half-Life I can see myself replaying Opposing Force again as well. In some ways its even better than the main game thanks to the quality of life improvements, GG.

[h1] Half-Life: Opposing Force это Half-Life, но вы играете за солдата понять это очень просто. При прохождении вы увидите как Гордон Фримен прыгает в портал, который ведёт в ЗЭН если хотите можете прыгнуть за ним, а что случится узнаете сами. Ещё кстати в этой игре и Half-Life: Blue Shift есть баг с мышкой. Чтобы от него избавиться надо в настройках мыши включить Raw Mouse Input (у кого руссификация- прямой ввод мыши)  и он пройдёт. Ну и я ставлю 10 из 10 [/h1]

Half-Life: Opposing Force review
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Pros:
+FPS
+The game shows how the soldiers in Half-Life felt
+You can obey or not obey orders
+Nice Boss at the end
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Cons:
-The graphics remained the same as from Half-Life
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Do I recommend Half-Life: Opposing Force?
